div.p: Hattige:
OR THE AMOURS OF THE KING OF TAMARAN.
A NOVEL.
AMSTERDAM, Printed for Simon the African, at the Black-Prince in the Sun, 1683.

div.head: THE PREFACE OF THE Tranlator.
div.p:
I Read in French this following Book over, in my Paage
from England into Holland; and finding it to pleae me very well, I reolved to make an Eay, to put it into Englih.

And in order to that, I found I had a great deal of leiure time to do it; for not being able to peak Dutch, and being not very deirous to learn it, I at often alone in my
Chamber, and in a few Days finihed this little Novel.
Which how well I have done it, let the Reader Judge. But let me put him in mind, that it is the firt Eay in this kind, or any other, that I have offered at.

I will ay omething as to the Original, that I think it is as full of Intrigues,
and thoe managed as well, and the whole Deigne carried on, as probably, as it is poible for any thing of this Nature to be; and that the Deign is laid with great Art, and managed with as good a Wit.

If the Reader receive this Book favourably, I do promie him, that I will in a little time
make him amends with omething of a more uefull Subject.

Although I cannot but acknowledg, that I think it equall to any of Scaroons, or the more Famed D. Miquel de Cervantes, and hath been eteemed o abroad: For in this mall time ince it came forth, which is not four years ince the
firt Printing of it here at Amsterdam, I have een four other Editions, one of London, one of Paris, and another at Colen, and the lat at Bruxels; which is the mot imperfect Copy of all.

I think I have aid enough, and deire the Reader to excue me, and pardon all the Errors that are committed
in the following Dicoure; By,

div.head: HATTIGE: OR, THE KING of Tameran's AMOURS.
div.p:
OF all places of the world, the Sea is fullet of Adventures, but not thoe of Love; 'tis the Scene Fortune mot delights to play her Pranks in; but that Element is too boyterous to agree with the tendernes of the Sex: Yet Love derives his Original from the Sea, which gave birth to his Mother; and though Gallantry be a Rarity
there, it cannot appear trange where Venus was born.

A young Knight of Malta, (which Character peaks him of Eminent Quality) full of generous emulation for the bravery of his Brethren of the Order, reolv'd in puruance of the Duty of his Profeion to follow their teps, in eeking Honour, by making War againt the Infidels: He came to Malta in a Frigat of 30 Guns, excellently fitted, and the bet Sayler that had of a long time gone out of that Port.

The Knight having performed his Land-ervices was grown a little acquainted with the Sea; but it was the firt time he commanded a Veel, and very glad he was, at his coming to Malta, to find Gourdan there, and made him an offer of being his Partner for Honour and Arms. Gourdan,
an Old Corair, very loth to admit a harer in Profit or Honour, and very rarely making ue of a Second in War, did notwithtanding accept the Propoal made him by a young Man, the mot hopeful of any that Order ever had. The Agreement was made, and the 15th of May they left Malta, and went to cruie on the Coats of Tunis, in hopes to meet with three Veels which Gourdan was informed were bound with Pilgrims for Mecha. The Wind was favourable, and in three days they were in Sight of Tunis: On the Fourth Gourdan's Veel drawing nearer the Coat, dicovered ome Sail, and dicharg'd a Gun to warn in his Partner.

The Sails he dicovered were thoe of the three Veels they went in earch of, which made
up to Gourdan, and attacqued him very vigorouly, and were glad to ee the Knight come up to econd him, making full account of him as a Second Prize. But 'tis no light dealing with the Coraires of Malta, whoe Cutom it is to fight to the lat, and dye before they yield: Thoe I am peaking of were trangers to fear, the one having long run an uninterrupted coure of Victory in all his Engagements, and the other upplying his want of Experience by incomparable Valour. I will not enlarge in particulars: The Fight was harp and bloody, the Turks having four times as many Men as the Chritians, and three Ships at leat as good as the Maltees.

Gourdan had kept aloof from the Enemy about a Musket hot, till the Knight came up, who
no ooner joyn'd him, but Gourdan would let him ee at what rate he had purchas'd his Honour in the Levant. He fell in furiouly among the Turks, and ply'd them o terribly with hot and Granadoes from both ides his Ship, that you would have thought him on Fire. The Knight, though he needed no Preident to teach him his Duty, yet glad to have a Man, Famous as Gourdan, witnes of his Actions, econded him o bravely, that the Turks, who till then made no doubt of the Victory, began to fear the ucces: They cool'd in their Attaques, and fell off to more ditance, not daring to grapple with the Chritians. The Knight had no ooner oberved it, but, to make ue of his advantage, which had viibly rais'd the Courage of his Souldiers, he
commanded them preently to Board the Ship that lay next him, being the toutet of the three; he was readily obeyed, and as readily ruhed a-Board the Enemy; a Company of Volunteers immediately followed him, with ome tout Souldiers, who, animated with his Example, did every one the Actions of Heroes. 'Twas wonderful to ee (though nothing more true) all the Decks covered with the Bodies of thoe Barbarians, lain at the firt Aault by a handful of Men: The Knight of Malta appear'd more than Man, he eem'd to be in ten or twelve everal places at once; o ready was he, and nimble, to help where need. But I forget my elf, to engage thus in decribing the Fight, which is not my deign, having a Thouand other things to ay, not of greater
importance (this Engagement being poibly the mot terrible and glorious happen'd on thoe Coats) but more ordinary and gallant, which my intention at preent is to entertain the Reader withal.

I hall add only, that after ix or even hours Fight, wherein you may believe there wanted not occaion for thee excellent Captains to ignalize themelves, the Veels having all boarded one another, the Chritians unk one of the Enemies, and put up the Standard of Malta in the main tops of the other two. Gourdan, who at that day thought no Man his equal at Sea, began to apprehend, from the Actions he had newly een, the Reputation of the young Knight might one day exceed his, and rob him
of the glory of Soveraign of thoe Seas: He had oberved him more than once enter the Enemy's Ships, and bear down all before him that offered to reit, and hewing his way to Victory through Wounds, Blood and Death; and that the honour of the Victory was almot wholly due to him: In a word, You are not to expect o much Jutice in the Old Coraire, as not to believe him jealous of the growing Reputation of his young Partner, and therefore les glad of the Victory, than otherwie he would have been.

The Knight had been wounded (though not mortally, yet) o dangerouly that he was oblig'd for ome Days to keep his Bed; the news was no ooner brought Gourdan, but he went to ee him, and expret the bet he could how much he was troubled at it; he
ended the Complement with all the Commendations and Praies, a Man jealous as he was of the young Knight, was capable to give. But the young Hero, no les modet than brave, put him off handomely, attributing to Gourdan the whole advantage of the Fight; only he did jutice to ome of his Ship, who had ignalized themelves mot, without aying a word of what he had done: They reolv'd to return to Malta to refit their Veels, and to ell the Prizes: Reolutions at Sea depend much on the Pleaure of the Winds; and they found themelves becalm'd on the morrow, which for three Weeks topp'd their deign, and render'd that a very tedious Voyage, which a Week before they had perform'd in three Days.

The Knight was oon well of his Wound, and finding himelf able enough to walk about in the Calme, he had a mind to take a view of the Prizes with Gourdan, who that day had given him a viit: He found them both coniderable for the number of Turks and Moors of both Sexes, which in a Chritian Country would be a current Commodity. When they return'd a-Board their own Ships, Gourdan's Lieutenant, being a Friend of the Knights, and not well atisfyed with his Captain, took an occaion, as they were peaking of the prizes, to tell the Knight privately he had not een the mot coniderable Prize, being a Turkih Lady of Eminent Quality, and one of the handomet Women that had ever been een. The Knight was urpriz'd Gourdan
had aid nothing of her, but looked on it as a Trick of an old Corair; yet he could not but be dipleaed with the proceeding as unjut and uncivil; but the Lieutenant told him, he was not to wonder at it from a Man who never knew what it was to be civil or jut to the bet of his Friends: He went on and told him how Gourdan had hifted the Lady into his Veel by Night, and plac'd her under the Guard of a Moorih Eunuch who had erv'd her long, and that Gourdan was o much in Love with her, and o jealous, he would not permit any one to ee her; that the Eunuch had told him the Lady had o great an Averion for Gourdan, not only for his uglines, but for his ill uage of her, that he was reolv'd to dye rather than comply with his deires. The Knight
was of too noble and generous a nature not to pity the poor Slave, epecially being handome, and no ordinary peron; he preently laid deigns in her Favour, and told the Lieutenant he would go ee his Captain on the morrow, and reproach him with having conceal'd that Treaure, in hopes to prevail with him, at leat to ue the Lady better, and end her back into the Veel he was taken in: The Lieutenant, better acquainted with Gourdan's humour, told him, it was more than he was to expect from one o deeply in Love, and o brutih as Gourdan. However the Knight went to ee him on the morrow: Gourdan receiv'd, cares'd, and entertain'd him with a great deal of kindnes, but not a word of the Slave: the Knight had of purpoe given him occaion to
dicoure of her, but Gourdan made him no atisfactory Anwer: At length the Knight, having lot all patience, ask'd him, as in raillery, if he knew what was become of a handome Turkih Woman, which he was told had been taken in the bigger Prize; and told him, he was much urpriz'd he had not een her when they took a view of what was found in the Turkih Ships, and that he had aid nothing of her: The Amorous Corair took this for an Affront, and told him roundly he knew not what Woman he meant, that they had een Women enough in the Prizes; that true it was he had one in his Ship who was no handomer than the ret; but, if that troubled him, there were enough left, and he might go pick out one from amongt them
that hould pleae him bet. The Knight little atisfyed with the Anwer, reply'd very eriouly, that he held the Conditions of their Partnerhip o acred, that till they came to a dividend, he thought neither had right, without the privity and conent of the other, to appropriate to himelf any thing found in the Prizes: Gourdan was a Man of o hallow Dicoure he had not a word to ay for himelf, but, without any reply, roe up and went to walk on the Deck, leaving the Knight in his Cabbin; who, mutering up the Forces of his good nature and gentlenes, to tifle the reentment the cros uage of this avage Man had raied within him, reolv'd to win him to reaon by Civility; he followed him, and embracing him with a kindnes would have gain'd the
heart of a Beat of the Field, I have no deign, ays he, to contet with you for the fair Slave you have poet your elf of; 'tis a ort of Commodity I have no mind to deal in, but pray do not refue me the ight of her: Gourdan was quite deaf of that Ear, 'twas a ticklih Requet, and he did not intend to expoe her to the view of a young Man o handome as his Partner; he lov'd her too well to hazard her on uch an Adventure; and walking on till without anwering a word, he made it ufficiently appear to the Knight he mut hunt for other Game, as for this Gourdan reerv'd it for himelf; the Knight knew not whether he hould be angry or laugh at the proceeding, yet looking on Gourdan with more pity than anger, Few men in my Circumtances, ays he, would be
atisfyed with this uage; but you mut be comply'd with, make much of your Slave; the time may come you will be a weary of her, and then I may be allow'd the liberty of eeing her: Having aid this, he left Gourdan, and retir'd to his Ship.

A few days after, he ent Gourdan word he had taken his Counel, and was going among the Prizes in earch of a Woman to his mind, that might bear him Company; though in truth it was to find out one who could give him an account who he was the Old Corair had got aboard; and very luckily he met with one who had erv'd her long and took her a-board his Veel, where he treated her with more Civility and Kindnes than a Woman of her condition knew how to receive; he made her it
with him at Table, and us'd her o obligingly as confounded the poor Slave: She was neither young nor handome, and could impute the Favour to nothing but the pure generoity of the Knight, whoe good meen was ufficient aurance of the incerity of his actions: Her Mitres became inenibly the Subject of their dicoure, and the Maid wanted not wit to atisfy his curioity: She told him her Mitres was a Lady the King of Tamaran had been paionately in Love with, and out of remore of Concience he was going a Pilgrim for Mecha: The Knight, who knew perons of that Quality did not without great reaon perform acts of o extraordinary devotion, asked her merrily, whether he knew the caue her Mitres became o extremely Pious; and eeing her
dipos'd to conceal nothing from him, he pray'd her to tell him the whole tory, not doubting but the account of the devotion of a woman of that Character mut needs contain more then ordinary adventures: Razy (the Slave he convers'd with) was by this time o taken with the Knight he would not have deny'd him a far greater matter, and without further intreaty poke to this purpoe.

Tamaran is a Kingdom where Love at this day reigns more abolute, than ever he did at Cyprus or Granada: Gallantry is become o much in ue there, 'tis almot as natural to be a Gallant, as to live, they are wholly given up to Love, and the young People, incourag'd by their Fathers Examples, get themelves Mitrees before they get rid of the Rod of their School-Mater. In a word, from
the age of fifteen to ixty, from the King to the Plowman, every one enjoys his natural Liberty: whether it proceed from the nature of the Clymat, or temper of the People, I cannot reolve you; I rather think Subjects are uch as their Kings make them. And the King of Tamaran being one of the mot gailant Princes the World ever had, 'tis no wonder there is nothing o much talk'd of in his Kingdom as Gallantry. But to come to my Story; that King, when he came to his Crown, fell in Love with Hattige my Mitres, who is certainly one of the mot beautiful Women eye ever aw. She is the daughter of a Janizary, and was married to a Peron of Quality, who had a competent Etate, ufficient to make her happy, had not her ambition preferr'd the Title of Mitres
to a King, before private Felicities: To horten the dicoure, the good Man found himelf oblig'd to endeavour to content himelf with the Honour the King did him in giving him a Title, and an Imployment abroad, which he carce took for a Favour, and would have been better pleas'd His Majety had betowed it on another.

My Mitres, proud and handome as he is, wanted not the addres to put a value on her elf, and ell His Majety a Conquet of that importance, at a rate uitable to her height of Spirit and Beauty: True it is, he hath not been admir'd for her wit, but that defect is upply'd by the obligeingnes of her carriage, and womens Little Arts, which he makes ue of o much to the purpoe of gaining the Monarchs
heart, that never Prince was o deeply in Love as he: he hath that complaiance and care to pleae her, as never man had for any Woman. And he hath not lot the advantage of it, but is by degrees become abolute Mitres of his Soul, and hath reaped the benefit of her conquet in all particulars, a woman that knows the World, and is tudious of her interet, can propoe to her elf. The Government of the Kingdom was in a manner in her hands: every one made his court to her, and whoever expected Favours or Rewards, mut apply himelf to Hattige, by whom all was granted, as the pipe that convey'd the Royal bounty to the Subject: Pat ages have furnihed us with Examples of this nature, and poterity may ee the like, but not equal to this; for it may be aid,
without tretching too much, the King of Tamaran took his Crown from his head to put it on Hattige's: The firt Day he aw her he fell deperately in love with her: the great rie of my Mitres and her power at Court, raied her many Enemies: yet her Pride and height of Spirit procured her more hatred than her favour did jealouie: But the mot coniderable and mot dangerous Enemy he had, was Oman, chief Aga and Favourite to the King.

A Favourite & a Mitres are eldom een to agree, either of them endeavouring to engros their Maters affection, is conequently engag'd for the ruin of the Rival: yet perons of that character for the mot part go cunningly to work; but thoe I peak of declar'd open War one againt the other, being both great pirits, & willing to let
the World ee the advantage they had one over the other: the King very prudent, and of a very peaceable humour, ided with neither, but having a kindnes for both, and knowing they hated one another, he gave neither of them credit in any thing aid to the diadvantage of the other: Oman, after many vain attacks, reolv'd at lat to try what jealouie might work on his Mater, and hoped his Paion, like that of other Lovers, might plit on that Rock: He apply'd himelf diligently to oberve the Conduct of the Lady, and find out ome coniderable and well grounded caue of upition, being throughly convinc'd his Mater was o taken with the Charms of the Lady, it would be no eaie matter to diabue him, and that he had cunning enough to clear and work her elf again
into Favour unles the crime were great and plainly proved.

My Mitres look'd not like an Enemy to Nature, and her illutrious Lover being (as uual) les amorous in his viits than he had been at firt, it was not improbable her contitution might force her to make ue of a Gallant to her mind, to atisfie her inclinations: at leat the Aga thought o, and you will find he was not deceiv'd.

The Title of Mitres, and Chief Mitres to the King (beides the power it gives perons of that Character) hath introduc'd much Liberty into the Serrail. Hattige who never tinted her elf in any priviledge he had, was in a manner Soveraign there, not a peron daring to contradict her in any thing: The Aga was no les coniderable, and omewhat more
formidable, and having Money at command (which is omnipotent at Court) he quickly by that means, had his Spies in every Corner, who promis'd him a faithful account of my Mitrees Actions.

As glorious as it is for an ambitious Woman to ee at her Feet every day a peron who commands all others, yet Monarchs are deceived if they think their Mitrees are always true. No paion, but that of extraordinary love, can fix a Womans heart; Ambition alone is too weak a gage for their Fidelity; it frequently happens, Princes owe their Amorous Conquets more to their quality than merit; and accordingly they extend only to what is external and gros, when Love and Inclination, frutrated of their expectations from them,
and not atisfied with pomp and with hew, goes in earch of atisfaction elewhere. Hattige lov'd the King, as mot Mitrees of that kind ue to do; that is, as far as the power of a Monarch could make her Love a Man, who raied her above all other Women; he reign'd in all outward plendor imaginable; but amidt all her Glories he was troubled he found not a Man he could Love for his own ake. A Woman ubject to uch reflections as thee, is hardly kept within the bounds of her duty; my Mitres found it too hard a task not to trangres a little, and being in earch of one worthy her condecention, he cat her Eyes upon Rajep, the Mater Gardiners Nephew.

Rajep was a handome Gentleman, young and vigorous, and
had pleas'd other Women, and was reputed to make his Fortune that way. She had twice or thrice een him, as he look'd upon the ports as are uually hewn for the divertiement of the Ladies of the Serrallio, where Men Fight with Beats for the pleaure of the Women. Rajep was excellent at the port, and always came off with Applaue and Admiration. Every blow he gave carried Death with it, and made all the Company hout for joy, which reached my Mitrees heart. 'Tis not unuual to find women affected with a Mans merit, upon occaions of that nature; he was deeply enible of the Applaue and Honour betowed by the Company on Rajep. When he came from thee Shews he could not forbear being melancholly and penive, even in the
King's preence; She could neither eat, nor Sleep. This troubled extremely the amorous Prince, who was o inquiitive after the leat concerns of the health and pleaures of his Mitres, that he was more in pain than he, to ee her languih as he did: He could not imagine what he ailed, and was o much concern'd at it, he could not ret for thinking of it. The Lady was more and more Love-ick, and by degrees her paion grew o upon her it altered her quite. The good King redoubled his Carees no les than his Care and Liberality; and if it had been poible, would have doubled his Love: He prayed her every moment, if he lov'd him, to tell him the caue of her trouble, and proteted he would not tick, for her atisfaction, to acrifice his
Life: So great, o true, and o tender a paion, might have turn'd that fale heart of hers, had he been capable of any love for him. But Rajep was her man; the mot charming in her Eye; and the mot accomplihed on Earth. The King's bounties he thought were but her due; or at leat ufficiently requited in the uperficial acknowledgments he made him; and that if he lov'd him not heartily, 'twas not her fault, but his, who knew not how to gain her Affection.

Such, Sir, is the fortune of Monarchs in love; when they are with their Mitrees they commonly lay aide that Majety which dazles the Eyes, and affects the Hearts of Mankind; they go undreed into their Chambers, and make themelves o familiar with their Mitrees,
they afterwards ue them as ordinary Men: The amourous Hattige, wholly poet with her paion for Rajep, languihed under it, not knowing what remedy to ue. Zara, a Greek Slave, and her chief Confident, had a longing deire to know what the matter was; he heard her igh every moment; and, like a Woman of Age and Experience as he was, he thought, if it was not for Love, there was no great danger: She was not over haty to know the Secret; but conform'd her elf o much to her Mitrees way of living, that he neither eat, nor lept; but wept, and igh'd, and walk'd, jut as her Mitres. At lat, my Mitres having often oberved it, ask'd her what he ailed to afflict her elf o: Alas, if you knew, Madam, anwers the good Matron, ighing, if you
knew, ays he again, with a orrowful Tone, what danger you run into by living as you do—But what hould I tell you of it, who have o little confidence in me. You have no caue to complain of that, Anwers Hattige, miling; for you know no peron alive knows more of my Secrets than You. Yes, Madam, relplyes Zara, till now, becaue poibly you never were engag'd in any thing might deerve the Name of a Secret; but now that the time is come to try my fidelity, to make ue of my Advice and Addrees, you are content to afflict your elf, as if you had not Zara with you; Zara, who loves you, (if I may be allowed to ay o) more than her Life, which he would very willingly acrifice for you: for what is the matter, Madam, what would you have? wherein may I erve you? why do you not make
ue of me?—Thou peaket, ays the Lady, as if thou readet what is in my heart. And who is it, but can gues, replyes Zara, what you ail? the only wonder to me is the King hath not taken notice of it, and I tremble when I hear you igh before him: for, when all's done, what is it you want for compleat atisfaction? if it be not that he loves you too much, and you love not him; there is not that thing you can deire in the world but you have it already. I tell you truly, Madam, I am afraid your Melancholly will at length make him upect omething, and what he will think of it I know not. Thou ayet well, poor Zara, replyes Hattige, eemingly affected with the kindnes of the good Slave; and could I believe thee faithful enough to acquaint thee with all that is in my heart, I doubt
not but thy Advice might be to my advantage. If you doubt my Fidelity, ays Zara, you need only ay nothing to me, for o you will oblige me, in pight of my heart, to keep your Counel: Yet I would have you know, that for forty years I have pent in the Serrail, I have been always look'd upon as an Example of Dicretion: There hath not been here in all that time a gallant Woman but I have erv'd; and were we at leiure, could give you a very pleaant account of them. In a word, Madam, I know who I am, and I know what you want. Make ue of me once more, and as oon as you pleae: Perhaps you may not find me always in humour to pleaure you, but it pities me at preent to ee you languih. My Mitres, who had before a good Opinion of Zara, and clearly aw how neceary he was for
her, reolv'd immediately to dicover all to her, though to ave her modety he turn'd the tory thus.

p.U:
ays he, I had a Brother who loved me, and I from a Child lov'd him with the tenderet Affection: My Father, to prevent miadventures he apprehended from the violent Inclinations we had one for another, parted us, ending him to Candy, whence he never return'd. Never were more Tears hed then by me on that cruel occaion; and to this Day I have not wore out the orrow for the los of him: But it is not that I have to ay to you, dear Zara, you know it already; what I am to acquaint thee with, is, I have een a man o like my dear Brother, in Meen, in Features, in Stature, in Actions; in a word, o every way like him, I verily thought him the
ame; and I had without doubt taken him for my Brother, had I not been told he was the Mater-Gardiner's Nephew. Who, Rajep, ays Zara! Yes, Rajep, the very ame,anwers Hattige; as high as Fortune raies us, ee how cruelly he ues us ometimes; for, you may believe, I could not ee this man but my Heart bled afreh with grief for my Brother; but the wort of all this, which I am almot ahamed to tell thee, I have, by a trange Sympathy, the ame inclination for him I had for my Brother; and the ight of this Man hath not only forc'd Tears from my Eyes, but ighs from my heart: What wouldet thou have me ay more? I find my el o unhappy, that 'tis my ill fortune not to love any, but whom I cannot or ought not to love.

div.p:
Hattige with that dropp'd ome Tears, which the officious Zara endeavour'd to top. No, no, adds Hattige, there is no Remedy for me but Death. The Age of dying for Love is long ince pat, ays Zara; trouble not your elf with the thoughts of a Vertue which is a Stranger to our times. What wouldet thou have me do then, ays Hattige? You hall know, anwers Zara, when you have told me what 'tis you deire. And eeing Hattige in a tudy what to ay, to give Zara time to gues what he wiht for; Would you ee Rajep, ays Zara? would you have me bring him to your Apartment—? Ah my dear Zara, cryes the amorous Lady, embracing her tenderly! how pleaantly thou flatteret mot paionate deires; could't thou do that for me, thou wouldet Eternally oblige me; but I am heartily
afraid for thee, and would rather dye than any harm hould happen to thee on my account. Take no care for that (ays Zara) this is not o great a matter for me to effect. I have already taken my meaures how to bring it about; do but write a Billet to Rajep to advertie him of his good Fortune, and let me alone with the ret. My Mitres, to encourage her the more to erve her faithfully, preented her with a Gold Chain, and aur'd her it was but the Earnet of what he would do for her. Pen, Ink, and Paper being brought, Hattige writ this Billet to Rajep.

q.p:
LOve, as well as Fortune, ometimes betows favours where leat expected: A Lady deires to ee you; the acces will be omewhat difficult, but you will not repent
the pains you hall take; uually the dearer we purchae any thing the better we eteem it: Prepare yonr elf to receive the good Fortune is offer'd you, and to purchae it with the peril of your Life: Your Courage is known, and if you find Fortune as favourable as Love you cannot be unhappy.

div.p:
Zara took the Billet, and went to give it an Eunuch he confided in mot; he had everal he employed on uch Errands, whoe Faithfulnes he bought with good ready Money: he carefully intructed him he ent on this Meage, and conjur'd him to Secreie. But what trut is there to be repoed in thoe who are alwayes for him that gives mot? Zara's pay was not comparable to the Aga's; and that Eunuch being one of his Spyes, you may
believe he carryed him the Billet in confidence of a good reward. Oman receiv'd it as the bet Preent could be made him; and impatient to ee what it contained, he retir'd into his Cloet; open'd it; knew the hand; read it over and over with that extremity of revenge, that attends the deire of pleaure, when in a hopeful way of being Mater of the Life or Reputation of an Enemy.

He paus'd a while e're he came to a reolution what to do with the Billet; to Copy it out would ignifie nothing, nothing being more to eaie then to deny what we have not written; to keep it, were to put a top to a buines, which, (to appear of coniderable conequence) mut be carryed on further: Having thought well of it, he was of Opinion it would be bet to keep the
Original, and end Rajep a Copy, which he caued a Woman to make of it, and end it to Rajep; who knowing neither the Character, nor the Peron that writ it, would be eaily taken in the nare: The Meenger very faithfully deliver'd Rajep the Billet; the Gallant, who lov'd no port better, was o proud of the Honour he receiv'd by it, that he would willingly have gone preently to ee what they would have with him: But his time was not yet come, he knew not the Lady who had o much kindnes for his Peron. He thought of everal, but this Eunuch belonging to the Serraillio, the Billet in all probability came from thence, where Rajep was altogether unacquainted. He could not imagine Hattige hould be the Peron; he, who was the proudet, as well as handomet,
Lady of the Kingdom, and the King's Principal Favourite: He would have ask'd the Eunuch, but feared he might poyl all by being too curious: This made him content himelf with asking a few Quetions for ome further light; but finding, by the Anwers, all he was to hope for at that time was the Billet; he dimit him with this Anwer.

q.p:
THere is nothing too hard for me, when concern'd in the Service of Ladies: 'Tis the duty of a civil Peron, to endeavour to oblige them: I take uch delight in it, I always think my Life well expos'd in their Service: You may gues, Madam, how ready I am on uch an occaion as this; let me but know the way I am to take, no Obtacle hall top me: I dye
with impatience to engage in the Affair, and if Fortune be not wanting to her duty, I hall quickly be where Love would have me.

div.p: The Eunuch was liberally paid by Rajep that moment for betraying him; he gave him a fair Diamond, & the honet Agent, in acknowledgment of the favour, went directly with the Billet to the Aga; who, ravihed at the good ucces, caus'd a Copy to be made of this as of the former Billet, and ent it to Hattige.

The paionate Lady at the return of the Eunuch, having read Rajep's Anwer, was o overjoyed, that the whole Serrallio rung of the News; he embraced her dear Zara a thouand times over; he cares'd the very Eunuch, who (you ee) deerv'd it well at her
hands; he rewarded both liberally, and promis'd them o largely, the performance would have ruined her: The fair Lady was o impatient he writ a new Billet on the morrow, and the Eunuch, who had erv'd her o Faithfully with the firt, was truted with the econd: He carry'd it (as he had caue) to the Aga, who opened it with as much joy as the former, and found in it thee words.

q.p: A Sight of you is enough to convince one, you are a very gallant man, and that one cannot hazard too much to engage with you: Make good ue of the Sentiments you rasie in thoe that ee you; do as the Moor hall tell you, and you will quickly have reaon to thank Love for his favours.

div.p: Oman having read the Billet, ask'd the Eunuch the particulars of his new Embay; who told him, He carryed Rajep the Aignation of a Rendezvous at Night, with the hour and the manner he was to be introduc'd. The Aga more joyful of the news than can be expret, caus'd a Copy to be made of this Billet by the hand that had copied the other, and dimis'd the Eunuch to purue his Commiion: Rajep, who did not expect o great a progres in o hort a time, thought himelf highly obliged to the fair Làdy unknown, who av'd him the Troubles and Inquietudes of longer delayes. His Anwer was this.

q.p:
WHatever you think of me, Madam, I have not vanity enough to fancy I
can merit the favour you do me. I acknowledge I owe it entirely to your Goodnes; and if I have any thing worthy of it, it is the extreme paion I have had for you now a whole day; a paion o violent, had you delay'd any longer my happynes of eeing you, it would have certainly been the death of me. I will do as directed; and if I fail of my deign, it hall not be for want of Love; it will be entirely Fortune's fault, which will undoubtedly be for me, if he favour thoe who are deepet in Love, as he does thoe who are boldet in Action.

div.p:
The Aga was glad of this Billet alo; had it copied; and ordered the Eunuch to bring him word as oon as Rajep entred the
Seraglio; which he punctually did about one a Clock in the morning. It was a little too late to carry the News to the King; but it was an Occaion to good to be lot: He went his ways, and found the King jut going to Bed. The King urprized to ee him come into his Chamber; What (ays he) Oman, up at this time of the Night! Nothing but good Fortune hould keep a Man o long awake. Who knows (ays the Aga) but 'tis that brings me hither. You are come a little too late (ays the King) and I am o well pleaed with my good Fortune to day, I will not rie to go in earch of a better. Hear me (adds the King, oberving Oman very deirous to interrupt him) I will tell you part of the Pleaure I have had this Evening, and hall not relih it o well, unles I acquaint you
with it: You mut know, that Hattige, whom (in pight of the hatred you have for her) you will acknowledge one of the handomet Women you have ever een, was fallen of late into o trange a Melancholly and Grief, that nothing could divert her: She did nothing but weep; and her Tears troubled me o, that at lat I believe, I hould have died for Grief; o great is the Love I have for her: This Day more charming (to Me at leat) and more beautiful than ever, (though not without ome languihing in her Looks, which hewed he was not throughly well at Heart) taking pity of the Condition her Sadnes was bringing me to: Sir (ays he) embracing me with extremity of Tendernes, I ee well enough what you uffer for my ake: Were my Life only concern'd, I would dye a Thouand times, rather than tell you the
caue of my melancholly; but the care I have of your Health, far dearer than mine, and the Concern I am under, to ee you o altered in few days, will not permit me any longer to conceal from you the caue of my adnes. I mut tell you then, though I were ure to loe your Affection by it, my grief proceeds only from a dream I had lately, which made uch impreion on my pirit, I cannot to this moment get it out of my thoughts. At that, he top'd, not able to proceed for weeping and obbing, which he could not forbear; and I had much ado to perwade her at length to put an end to; and preing her more earnetly to go on, and tell me her dream. Alas! (continued he, ighing) may it not be a fatal Prediction out of my own mouth againt my elf? I dreamt, Sir, I aw you in Roukia 's arms, the Mater Gardiner's Wife, and
was not able with tears or reproaches to force you thence. Can you be o fale, and will you not endeavour at leat to divert the blow Heaven threatens me with?

Ah, Sir, rather let me die, than ever ee this come to pas. Here her grief eiz'd her more violently than ever, and he fell half dead into my Arms. You may believe, dear Oman, I aid many things to her to bring her again, and perwade her out of the thoughts of the Dream, which you know ignifies nothing. I have often heard talk of Rouchia; but as beautiful as they report her to be, I never had the curioity to ee her. I was o atisfied with the lovely Hattige, for whom I have reolv'd to keep my elf entirely, and tick to her alone. To end my Story, you mut know, I prevail'd with her o far, with oaths and kind words, that I diabus'd
at lat, and left her perfectly cur'd of thoe upitions of falnes he had entertain'd againt me. She recover'd her former Gayety of humor, and was kinder than ever, having expret to me all the tendernes and trength of an extraordinary Paion; I tay'd with her longer than ordinary, and am more in love with her than ever. I am but newly come from her, and to tell you the Truth, had carce the power to leave her Pray tay a little longer, (ays he till) as I was going. And till one moments tay procur'd another, full of love and of kindnes; which eem'd to increae till as he taid me: I could entertain you all night with the pleaure I had in the Cloet of that charming Woman; and yet not tell you all, which, you know, is not dicretion in a Lover to do to his Confident, though never o faithful.
But what think you of her tendernes for me? Was ever woman in love o allarm'd at a Dream? And mut I not love her more than ever, for having endur'd what he did, without daring to acquaint me with it? 'Tis true, (ays the Aga very eriouly) what you have aid, is urprizing, but not to that degree you imagin'd. Give me leave to acquaint you only, that a Man for whom I have the highet repect and veneration, being paionately in Love, as you are, with a Woman, one day in confidence gave me an account how pleaantly he had pent ome moments in her Company; and that he had given him a tate of all that the mot tender and paionate Love hath of weet, and of charm; and that he thought himelf the happiet Lover on Earth. You would think your elf much
abus'd, (aid I) if all thoe tranports of Love and of tendernes you have been o taken with, were but a Doe of Poyon to cat you into a leep; and that the Lady you peak of, is at this moment in the Arms of another. There was nothing o true, Sir, (adds the Aga) as what I told him; that man, if he had pleas'd, might have been an eye-witnes of it. I could have let him have een his Mitres in Bed with another man, o far beneath him, as a Subject is beneath a Prince.

Oman, Oman, (ays the King) you hall not make me jealous: I believe (continues he, looking earnetly on the Aga) uch a thing might happen. Women are now adays o treacherous, there is no truting their Carees. But I am very well atisfied I cannot be concern'd in o infamous an Example. I know Hattige
and know her too well, to believe he ever had kindnes for any but me. However, (replies the Aga) 'tis of you I am peaking all this while; and ince I mut be plain with you, and that the honour of my King is concern'd in it, you are the Peron o baely dihonour'd. 'Tis that charming Hattige, whom you love and adore o, 'tis he betrays you this moment, in the manner I have told you. The King, atoniht with the udden troke of uch terrible News, was peechles a while; but preently after, looking angerly on the Aga; As long as your invectives, Oman (ays he) extended only to the pride and exceive Expences of Hattige, I had the patience to bear with them, as having ome ground of Truth; but her Reputation being in quetion, wherein mine is o deeply concern'd,
I hall think very ill of you, if you accue her without good proof to convict her: 'Tis now almot three Years ince I aw Hattige, and have reaon to know her better than any: Had there been another in the Kingdom greater than my elf, or were any one my equal in it, I might peradventure have ome apprehenion he might be guilty of uch a Crime: I ay, peradventure; for I doubt very much, whether he would in that Cae be fale to me. But conidering her pride and height of Spirit, you hall never make me believe he can abae her elf to think of any thing below me, unles I ee it with my Eyes: Do not I ee how he ues all the World, and that there is not a more ambitious Woman living? Certainly he loves me. Yet I am perwaded, he would love me more, were I greater than I am; for nothing
but Greatnes can atisfie that proud Soul of hers. I knew very well, (anwers the Aga, ighing for pity) Thus prepoet, or enchanted rather, as you are, in favour of that Lady, what I hould ay againt her, would make little impreion on you: I do not deire you hould believe it, if you have not a mind to it: yet be pleas'd to come, and ee it with your own Eyes? What you! Can you let me ee, (crys the King very angrily) when I am but jut now come from her? Well Sir (ays the Aga) What you ay is true, but it is no les true, that if you pleae, you may find her with another in her Chamber, if you pleae to take the pains of going thither. Ah! (ays the incredulous Prince) I can have no more patience: But have you conider'd, Oman, how highly I hall reent it, if I take the
pains to get up, and you cannot convict her of the Crime you charge her with? The Aga very calmly anwers; I am well aur'd of what I ay; and have no caue to fear your Reentment, if I have no more to do than let you ee what I promis'd. The King got up, and having put on his Night-Gown, with his Turban, and Sword, he went treight towards the Seraglio with Oman, holding him by the hand, as if he had fear'd he would have given him the lip. This is the Scene, (ays the King at his entrance) where, what you have promis'd me, is to be een; but take heed you bear not a part in the Catatrophe. The Aga told him, 'twas a plain matter of Fact would be preently dicover'd. The King oberving him come on o reolutely, and with joy in his face, as a man going
to a Triumph, began (not altogether to believe him, but) to fear there was omething in the matter: And it made him the rather apprehend ome untoward Adventure, that he knew Oman a Man of good ene, and not eaily mitaken; and one, who without very good grounds, would not have engag'd in a buines of that nature: So that the King knew not what to think. He would not for his life have given him that advantage over his Mitres; epecially after the Story he had jut then told him. And now all the Kings care was to make the deign of the dicovery micarry, though he were criminal: When they were got within two or three teps of Hattiges Apartment, and had no more to do but draw the Curtain, the King eem'd, as if he knew not
whither he was to go, nor what he had to do. His Guide, jealous of his Honour, and eager to make him an Eye-witnes of his hame, was forc'd to puh him on, and mind him there was no time to be lot, if he would find them o together as was neceary for a clear Conviction, and if he taid any longer, the whole Serrallio would know they were in: The King heard him not, or made as if he had not: He was buying himelf with needles precautions of hutting up Doors, which (beides that there was no need to have them hut) made a great noie if they were tirr'd; of placing Guards in needles places, and calling for help, that they within might hear him. In a word, to mad the Aga (who pent his breath in telling him he mut not tay, but go directly
to Hattige) for one tep he advanc'd he went back two: At lat he order'd the matter o that the Gallant was aware of his coming, and had time to ecape, o that when the King was come to the Lady's Chamber, the Bird was flown, and no other ign of her guilt, but a little more than ordinary finery, and a dres very different from what the King left her in, which would have pat for good proof with a Lover les blind than he: Hattige had the dexterity to invent everal pretences to take off the upition of any deign; and to be beforehand with the Monarch, he told him, he had pleas'd her o well that Evening, that, to charm him on the Morrow more than ever he had done, he had try'd on ome new Drees, and he was come mot luckily to tell her how he
lik'd them. Yet he mut confes her elf a little urpriz'd at his udden return, and extraordinary Viit; and that either his paion for her was increas'd that Evening, or that he had ome particular Reaons for it, which he could not gues, but might detroy all the pleaure he took in eeing him the econd time. The King, perplext at what he aw, anwer'd her very coldly, as if he had not been atisfi'd with her Excue, and let her know by his looks, he had ome upicion of the Bravery he found her in; yet he durt not condemn her, as wanting ufficient reaon for it. Oman, who taid in the next Room, and had, by his Maters fault, lot o excellent an occaion, was ready to eat his Fingers for madnes, raving and exclaiming againt the weakness of his Patron, and
calling him all the Names his anger could ugget.

The good Prince, who had too much good nature to be proof againt the obliging Kindnes and Flatteries of his Mitres, was not only quickly perwaded to believe all he aid, but (which is mot incredible) he had the Goodnes to tell her the reaon of his Viit, and all that the Aga had acquainted him with. Then it was it rain'd Torrents of Tears; then was her Hair pull'd by handfuls, her Head-gear and Cloaths tore all to pieces and a thouand other Actions of Depair o extraordinary, that the King to appeae her, was forc'd to ask her pardon. Oman knew nothing of all this, when his Mater entred the Chamber Oman was in, and with rears in his Eyes pray'd him if he lov'd him, to go make the
innocent Hattige ome reparation of Honour: This put Oman into uch indignation he almot lot his repect to his Mater, who continuing obtinate to have him make a ubmiion o unjut and unbecoming a Man of his Quality, Oman took out the four Billets which he had of purpoe brought with him, to jutifie what he had aid, if there hould be occaion, and hewed them the King, asking him if he knew the Character of thoe Hattige had written. Then he pray'd the King to give him leave to retire, which he granted him, more for hame he knew not what to ay to him, than for any other reaon he had to get rid of him: What an atonihment was the poor Monarch in, at ight of the Billets? It was not in his power to come to himelf; he
walk'd all alone about the Room, with his head to the ground, (pres'd down, you may believe, with the new weight it bore) and his Heart full of extraordinary Conflicts and violent Emotions.

My Mitres, (urpriz'd the King tay'd o long) was afraid the Aga might poil all, and mar what her tears had o well mended, and would go her elf to ee what the matter was: She found him muing as a man in a maze, and going up to him, and embracing him, in that fond and obliging manner, where with he charm'd him when he pleas'd; What troubles you now, Sir, (ays he,) that you ue me o cruelly? Any new trick of the Aga's? Will he never have done contriving of michief? Ah Heavens! How unfortunate am I (adds he, wetting his Face with the Tears
that fell from her Eyes) to ee you o eaie to believe thoe horrible Calumnies that Villain invents of me? With that he fell as half dead into his Arms, which o oftned the Heart of the kind Monarch, he could no longer reit uch Charms; but embracing her with unparallel'd Tendernes and Sorrow, carry'd her in his Arms, and laid her on the Bed, praying her, with Tears in his Eyes, to come to her elf again, otherwie he mut expect to have him die with her.

This exces of Tendernes was too little to comfort the afflicted Fair One: She would know further, what the Traytor (o he call'd the Aga) had told him of new, and proteted he would not ceae crying till he had told her all, and he had jutifi'd her elf from all his Calumnies. The
good King was very loath to let her ee the Billets, fearing without doubt it would be hard for her to jutifie her elf againt them; but the deire he had to find her innocent, made him give 'em her; telling her, he was well aur'd, 'twas a new Impoture; and that he very well knew, 'twas an uual thing to counterfeit hands. She took the Billets, and began to read them; but with terrible Acclamations: Heaven! (ays he) Can man be o malicious? Well Sir, (adds he) what Arts, and what Indutry are made ue of to ruine me, and detroy me in your Opinion? And will you make nothing of it; but pas it by, and take no care to revenge me? Aure your elf, I will without more ado, caue to morrow morning aMaraboug to be made, where I'le bury my elf
alive, unles you do me Reaon, and clear my Reputation from o criminal an Imputation, which reflects no les on You than on Me. You have a Heart of Stone towards a poor Woman, who hath quitted all for Love of you, and made her elf a Sacrifice to your Paion; and in the mean time. permit your elf to be abus'd by a Favourite, a Villain, whoe Spirit and Ambition you know; and he can prevail with you, not only to do what ever he pleaes, but to believe the tranget and mot impoible things in the World.

What a hower of Tears ell with thee words? She had a Store-houe of them, and could command them thence in what quantity he pleas'd: The King did all he could to quiet her; he promis'd to vindicate her, and let her ee very uddenly, he was not
for Oman: Strange Weaknes! But Kings in love are Men, and not Gods.

On the Morrow, the Aga was with the King at his riing, but received in a lamentable manner: He complained of him, and reproach'd him (you ee with what Grounds) and at lat banih't him, forbidding him his Preence, till he hould be ent for. Oman obey'd without Reply. He might have made more tir, by producing the Moor; but after Uage o hard and unjut, he would not be at the Pains; but choe rather to be thought to be in fault, and at ditance from a Mater o eaie to be educ'd by the Flatteries of a Woman, than to jutifie himelf for undeceiving him.

Many were amaz'd at the Favourite's Fall; ome rejoyc'd at it, epecially my Mitres; who having
now near the King no Enemy, but what he lighted, allowed her elf to take her full winge in her Amours, relying on the blindnes of the good Prince, whom he thought he had laid too oundly aleep, to fear his waking a good while. Her trouble was to dicover how the Aga came by the Billets: there was no colour of reaon to upect Rajep, who was not only too honet, to be capable of uch Treachery, but oblig'd by joynt interet not to accue her. The Eunuch, who had been the Mercury of the Intrigue, was the mot upicious. She ent in earch of him, but Zara could have no news of him, and o the Treaon came out. Hattige fail'd not to charge the Mitres of her Intrigues, to make better choice of thoe he imploy'd, and whom he truted as Meengers
in matters of that importance.

The King was too Amorous not to be ubject to jealouie. He could not put out of his head thoe Billets written in a Character o exactly like Hattiges, though he knew Folks have the art of counterfeiting hands: And taking time at his leiure, to examine in private, and weigh with himelf all the Circumtances of that Evenings Adventure, it made him for a while very unquiet, and full of vexation. At lat, he reolv'd for his atisfaction, and eae, to oberve in peron, the Conduct of his Mitres, to rid himelf at once of the Supicions that tormented him, or the Paion he had for her if guilty: He bethought himelf of a Stratagem for the purpoe, which hit very luckily.

He had the priviledge to enter the Seraglio, when he pleas'd,
through Doors made of purpoe, the Keys whereof were in his cutody. The Day he intended to put his Deign in Execution, he pent almot all in Hattiges Lodgings, paying her all the Amorous Devoirs he us'd to do, with more than ordinary Gaiety and Tendernes; inomuch that he thought him better atisfied than ever of her Fidelity to him: Beides he taid of purpoe, much later than ordinary, though to the good Ladys very great trouble, it being a Day of Aignation for Rajep, who with the impatience of a fortunate Lover, waited Zara's coming: But when a Peron who is jealous knows how to diemble, he deceives the mot mitrutful.

The King from Hattige's Lodgings went into his own, to dres himelf like a Bedowin (o they call the Moorih Women of the
Mountains, of whom there are commonly great numbers in the Serallio) his Face he cover'd with a black Vail, and his Body a white Blanket, and put on a pair of Linnen-Drawers, and black Stockings, which is all the Equipage of that ort of Women, when they are in the Towns; for in the Country they go as God made them. The King in his new Dres lipt oftly and alone into the Seraglio, and poted himelf before the Door of his Mitrees Apartment; where, to avoid upicion, he laid him down on a Bench, as the Bedowines ue to do.

It was a Gallery you mut of neceity pas through, whether you went in or out of my Mitrees Lodgings: At one end of it was a Lanthorn, which had a Light in it all Night; but the King being at the other end of the Gallery, it
was almot dark there. He had not long been on the Watch, but he dicover'd the Enemy, though he had no great mind to ask, Who goes there: He never bid them tand, but let them come on unditurb'd, that he might have them where he dear'd. 'Twas ev'n Zara, leading another Bedowine by the hand, whom the King prepoet with upicion, preently believ'd uch another Woman as himelf. And to peak the truth, the Bodowin's Stature and Gate confirm'd his conjecture. Zara went up to the door, never minding the Centinel, and turning towards her Bedowin, bid him have a moments patience, and he would go to her Mitres for Orders for his Entrance. The King had time then to take a full view of the Bedowine; who turning about toward
that ide where the King lay, perceiv'd there was omething in humane Shape on the Bench, and being now in an Enemies Country, the Bedowin thought She could not be too cautious, and for fear of leaving behind her fomething that might hinder her retreat, thought good to make up to what he aw, and examine nearer at hand what it was: Fortune, being commonly favourable to thoe Love expoes, order'd it o, that a corner of the Blanket the King had wrapt himelf in being untyed, the curious Bedowin dicover'd part of a Sword, which being Enamell'd with Vermillion, in that little light there was, gave the Bedowin enough to know 'twas time to look about her, and not afe to be there. Accordingly She went oftly to the other end of the Gallery, and o
down the Stairs, and away out of Doors; which he was very glad of, having cap'd a cowring, being fully perwaded the Sword he had een, threatne her Life.

The King, who thought he had not given his fellow Beaowin the leat upition, could not fancy her marching back was to run quite away. He got up to ee what was become of her: Zara, arriving, took him for the Bedowin he had left at the door, and wiper'd him in the Ear, he might enter, and be kindly receiv'd. The King, glad of the mitake, followed his Guide, leading him by the hand, a way he knew better than any one alive. He was no ooner got into Hattiges Chamber, but he took him about the neek, hugging him in her Arms with the Tranports of a Woman amorous as he. Dear
Rajep, (ays he) how glad am I to ee thee, having pent all this day with a King, whoe Carees are torments to me? Thou mut make me amends by a thouand Tranports of Love. This was an excellent beginning for the Monarchs Entertainment, who took all patiently, not tirring from under his Diguie: The Lady more haty than he, to make good ue of thoe pleaant moments the preence of a Lover, belov'd as he was hould produce, couldnot endure that o little delay. Her longings, more prevalent than her Modety, put her into a fit of charming Wrath againt the coldnes of her inenible Lover: he made him a thouand Reproaches, and would have tore off with her own hands his Vail, and his Blankets, and the ret of his fine dres: What, Rajep, (ays he) with
an amorous Indignation) do you expect that I hould unmak you? Have you no more Deire to ee and embrace me? Is the time you purchae, with the peril of your life and mine, of o little alue, that you can afford to loe o many precious moments? No oomer had he aid this, but down dropt the Diguie. Zara, who had helpt her Mitres to undres the fale Bedowin, firt dicover'd the mitake, and ran away with a hrieck that frighted her Mitres, who was never o urpriz'd as to ee 'twas the King. Hattige very luckily wouned away for fear, for 'tis very probable the injur'd Monarch would otherwie in the beginning of his fury, have been tranported into ome act of violence againt her, which might have mi- become him. But eeing a Woman almot dead at his
feet (though he did but counterfeit) his fury vanih'd, to give place to his pity, which eiz'd him with that Tendernes, that made him enible, fale and ingratefull as he was, he could not forbear loveing her till. He call'd to the Slaves of the Apartment, and order'd her to be laid on a Bed, where it would have pleas'd him to approach her with her Falhood; but finding his Reentment too weak for his good nature, melting at ight of an Object o amiable, though fale, he retir'd.

The next day Oman was call'd to Court, where he had from the King a very favourable Reception, to make him amends for his former hard Uage. He told him, he was but too much convinc'd of the ill Conduct of Hattige, againt whom he let fall
the mot opprobrious Language imaginable; proteting he would for the future ue her as the baet of Women. The Aga, being a dextrous Courtier, and not unacquainted with Lover's Relapes; knowing where lay the Weaknes of his Prince, aid not a word for, or againt her; only pray'd him to believe, he had not in his Kingdom, a Servant more faithfull, and jealous of his Mater's Glory, than him. But that he was afraid if his Majtey aw that Woman again, things would return to their former coure. The King bluh'd at thee words, as reproaching him with his frailty. Yet he wore a thouand Oaths, it hould never be o again, which his Heart mi-gave him he would not keep, as it afterwards hapned.

As for Rajep, Order was given
to apprehend him. Meharen, the Mater-Gardiner, having no Heir but that dear Nephew of his, when he had the News of what had pat in the Seraglio, and the Order againt Rajey, threw himelf at the King's Feet, but was preently rejected. Yet his Freinds at Court appeas'd the King in ome meaure, and prevail'd with him to change the Sentece of Death, pat againt Rajeb, into that of Banihment during Life.

My Mitres the firt, the econd, and third day of her Digrace, aw not the King: This was a long time for the amorous Prince, who us'd to be carce an hour away from her. Acquaintances of that nature are not lot, without a great deal of pain. She had Friends he imploy'd, who every moment acquainted the King with the lamentable condition
her Repentance had brought her to, being o pin'd away he was not likely to live an Hour. The fourth day the Propheie of Oman was fulfill'd. The King foftned with the ad News, melting into Tendernes, igh'd, taggerd, and at lat, following his Inclination, went to give her one Viit more, under pretence of taking his Revenge of her, being aham'd, without doubt, of o unbecoming a Relape, after the noie he had made of the Falnes of that Woman. To excue himelf, he aid he would go to her only, to take from her thoe Jewels he had given her, who deerv'd not to wear auy thing belonging to him. The Aga, who knew his Mater well, and of what Conequenee that Viit might be, would have diverted him dextrouly, by taking the Ladies part.

And telling him, It did not become a generous Prince, as he was, to repent of his Liberality, epecially to Women. But if he deign'd only to frighten her, (which he doubted not, was all he intended) it would uffice, as he conceiv'd, to end any one to her from his Majety, without doing her the Honour of a peronal Viit. The Counel was good, but uneaonable for a Lover, who was going in earch of what the other would have diverted him from. The King anwered, he knew what he did; and that in ome Affairs he lov'd to follow his Humour, without any Advice. The Aga by this judg'd all was lot, and that the King would be engag'd deeper than ever. He hrug'd and retir'd, unwilling to be Witnes of an Action, which would be charg'd half upon him,
if preent. The King was not dipleas'd as his retyring, and perhaps things would have gone otherwie then they did, had the Aga been there. The King came to Hattiges Apartment, where preently, without taying to give her notice of his coming, or calling for the Keys of the Cloet where the Jewels were, he caus'd the door to be broke open; entred it, and finding the box (they were in) open, he fell to viewing them over, and taking particular notice of them, as it were to give time to his perfi • ious Mitres to come, and appeae him. She fell down at his Feet, with her Hair about her Ears, and embrac'd his Knees with that irreitable tendernes, he took her up, and led her into the Cloet: what Reconciliation was made there, I know not; but certain it is, the
King left the Jewels behind him, and returning two hours after, made her new Preents.

This agreement by degrees gathered uch trength, that the Amorous Prince viited her oftner than ever, and eem'd to have forgotten, not only what he had aid of Hattige, but all that had pat; which for a Lover of his Character was of conequence enough, never to be forgotten. It was talk'd of abroad, but not much to his advantage. Only the Aga aid not a word of it. Being politique, he knew there was no remedy, and that it was an incurable Infirmity in his Prince, whoe Acendant was Love: So that the Aga held it imprudent in him, to ruin his Fortune to erve his Prince againt his will; and was confident, Hattige was a Woman of that humor,
he would detroy her elf at lat.

Rajep being banih'd, and Hattige more addicted to Gallantry than ever, (the King having caus'd her only to change her Gallant, and add to her former, the Pleaure of Variety) Zara, who through his means, was again taken into her Favour, was imploy'd a new to find out one with whom he might break thoe Oaths of Fidelity he had newly made to the King. Hattige did no longer mince the matter to this Slave, o well acquainted with her Concerns. And the good Matron, who knew her Mitres deir'd a Gallant, as well out of the Infirmity of her Nature, and Weaknes of Temper, as to pleae her Inclination; reolv'd to find her out one, with whom he alo might do her Buines. The King, on the other
ide, who after he was convinc'd of the Falenes of Hattige, began to love her les, was very deirous of a new Mitres, and fell in love with Roukia, as Hattige had foretold. It was an Inclination he was trangely urpriz'd into, and perhaps in a manner not to be paralell'd.

Women, beides the natural Beauty of the Face, which chiefly gains them Admirers, have a Thouand other ways to engage Men to love them; for their Voice, their Wit, their Humour, their Shape, their good Meen, and other Qualities, capable to produce great Effects in the Hearts of their Lovers. But I carce dare tell you, how Love brought the King enamour'd of Roukia, who being one of the Handomet Women of the Kingdome, charm'd him by that part,
of which he took the les care, becaue he would have been aham'd to hew it him, and would not have expos'd it to the Light, but for neceity, and without dreaming it could be the caue of o lucky an Effect. Excue me, Sir, (ays Razi) laughing, if I enlarge no further on this Sublect. You may gues by what I have aid, few Fih are caught with that Bait.

One Evening, about Sun-et, the King from the Terrae of the Garden of the Seraglio, looking through the Trees, had a ight of Roukia in that pleaant Poture: The Sun, who eem'd to tay to guild with his Rays, an Object o charming to that Prince, never aw any thing whiter, or better hap'd. 'Twas in truth a Materpiece of the kind, and (notwithtanding the unpleaing Function it was about) inflam'd the Heart
of the Royall Spectator, who did all he could to ee a little more; but Love would not permit it, being reolv'd the part he had firt een, hould have all the Glory of that Conquet. The morrow a Courier (for Gallantry) was dipatch'd with a Billet to Roukia, to this effect.

q.p:
I Love you, Madam, and love you with a Paion no les tender than new: I will not tell you how you have wounded me, but it was no les than an innocent Treaon. I have heard ay, you were dangerous to ee, but not of that ide I aw you: Others run away from the ight of that, wherewith I am taken, and it was my Fate to feel the Power of your Charms, by that which is commonly leat charming: However I am more in love, than any man living; and what will become
of me, when I ee you as I ought? I cannot tell. I have realon to fear an entire Defeat. I dye with impatience to expoe my fel to your mot powerfull Charms. I am preparing for you that Triumph, this Evening. Let me not languih; otherwie you will be the Death of your King, whom you have already too cruelly wounded, not to pity him a little. The Moore, who brings you this Billet, will tell you what is to be done. Adieu.

div.p:
Thus it is our Kings declare their Love: they never igh in vain. They need but ay, I love you, and I will, and the buines is done. Our Women think it their duty to obey them in matters of Love, as our Men in Affairs of State. Roukia, inclinable as the ret of our Countrey-Women, in things of that nature,
was o charm'd with the Honour of being written to by the King, that, without examining circumtances, he preently return'd him this favourable Anwer.

q.p: SIr, you are no les Mater of our Hearts, than our Lives: You hall never find me other, than full of Repect and Obedience towards you: Your Will is a Law. And Nothing hall be too hard for Me, when You command it to be done. The Direction I have from the Moor hall be oberv'd; You mut only take care to imploy Meharen about buines: All things ele will auredly be favourable. And if you love me as much as you ay, you will ave me part of thoe pains that attend the Impatience of one in Love, when forc'd to wait long.

div.p: The King receiv'd this Letter with the joy of a Lover, who was to be happy that day, which eem'd long to him; who was to tay till night, before he could go to the place of Rendezvous. He was o wholly taken up with his new Paion, and the pleaures he promis'd himelf from it, that he never thought of eeing Hattige, which he eldom fail'd to do. A Commiion was preently made ready to end Meharen out of Town. Night being come, the King went alone, & without noie into the Garden of the Seraglio, where the Comedy was to be acted by him and Roukia, who at the hour appointed came in by a Ladder he had caus'd to be brought for the purpoe.

This enterview was charming on either ide: The night was not o dark, but the King could
dicern Roukia's excellent Shape; and judging the Features of her Face to be anwerable, he made no doubt but he was beautiful, as he was reported: But what charm'd him mot, was her admirable Wit, which he hew'd on all occaions, to make him amends for what the Night hid from his Eyes. The King was tranported at it. And to tell you the truth, they pent not much time in Complement, but were quickly familiar, as if they had been acquainted many years. 'Tis a priviledge Kings have, to make more way in a day, than others in a Month.

Roukia, no les proud of the Honour the King did her, and the Dignity likely to attend it, than he was of his love, did her utmot endeavour to deerve it, & with admirable ucces; for he
gain'd his Eteem no les than his Affection. She aid a Thouand pretty things, which he was raviht at, and made him (very obligingly for her) blame Love for having been o low in bringing him acquainted with her, who deerv'd bet of any his A fection, and his Care: They were got into a Grotto, convenient enough for an Entertainment, almot like that of Aeneas and Dido; and were there for ome time, without Interruption. I will not diturb them, (continues Razy, miling) to give you an account what pat there between them. You have been in Love, I believe, and may gues what dicoure they had. The King it eems was well pleas'd with it, for he reolv'd to pas the ret of the Night there.

The Summer is the bet Seaon
for Rancounters of Love: but this being a Gallant us'd to Succes, afforded les matter of dicoure than one, who had been les fortunate would have done; and at length he fell aleep with his Fair one. Love, who had more Buines to do in the ame Garden, allow'd him but a hort time to ret. Roukia, hearing a Noie, awak'd him to tell him of it. At firt, he could hardly believe it, the place being inacceible to any but himelf, and Meharen, as Mater-Gardiner, whom he had ent abroad, and therefore had no apprehenion of: He hearken'd more attentively, and could hear ones voice, and afterwards his teps: Before he would proceed farther, he was willing to know who were o rah to enter that Place, which it was Death to do by Day, without his Permiion;
he was carce got up, but he ees them approach to come into the Grotto. It was a pacious Place made of purpoe for a Coolingroom in the Heats of Summer; and had in it everal Beds of Turf, very prettily made with Pots of Jeamin Flowers, and other Sweets, all about. In a word, it was a place pick't out for the Kings Pleaure. It appear'd, by the manner of the new Comers entry, they were no trangers to the Place. They choe a Quarter not far from the King's. But it was o dark, it was impoible to ee one another. He let them eat themelves at their eae, and had oberv'd they were two, but could not dicern whether Men or Women. One of them, whoe voice the King preently knew, ays immediately to the other; 'Tis the finet place in the world,
to laugh at the Jealous, and to be quit with them. He hath ometimes brought me hither, where I have been forc'd to pend with him many a tedious quarter of an hour. This was Hattige: The King was extremely urpriz'd, not knowing how he hould poibly have come into the Garden; but he was the more urpriz'd, and Roukia alo, at the anwer of the other, whom both knew to be Meharen: I confes, Madam, (ays he) he deerves not to poes alone the Affections of a Lady beautifull as you are, but he is my Mater. And nothing but a Paion, great as that I have for you, could have prevail'd with me to be fale to him, as I am. Nothing but the extremity of your Beauty, whoe charms are irriitable, could excue uch a Crime. But let a man value himelfe never o much
on his Honety and Integrity, yet a Paion rais'd in him by a Peron o amiable as you, will be Proof againt all Batteries of Duty, and eaily mater it. 'Tis but in jet, Meharen, (ays Hattige) that you raie thee Scruples: I am fale, as you are, but that's nothing with me. 'Tis a fine thing to be fale, if you know how to do it handomely. I have a Heart will be its own Mater, and love one to day, and another tomorrow. What would become of Men and Women, if, when they engage in kindnes with one, they mut abolutely ell themelves, and not be allowed to change, when they grow weary, or have a greater Inclination for another. 'Tis a natural Right to betow our Affections where we pleae, and when we pleae to revoke the Gift: And wretched are they, who enjoy not that Liberty:
Our Sentiments are ubject to Change, as other things; and Love as well as Nature is not charming, but in Variety: For Example, Meharen, to day I am for You, but three or four days hence I will not undertake but I may be for another. And it would be Injutice in you, to expect I hould be truer to You, than I am to the King. True, Madam, (replies Meharen, mileing) I have no Reaon to blame in you that amiable Incontancy, to which I owe my Happines: But would you ay as much to the King, Madam? You may believe, (ays She I glory not in thee Maximes before him, not for fear he hould follow them, but to avoid giving him Caue to have an ill Opinion of Me: Were He of my Humour, I think I hould love him the better, and perhaps I hate him for
nothing ele, but that he loves me too contantly. I have endeavoured handomly to engage him to be fale to me, inomuch that I told him one day, I dream'd I had een him in your Wife Roukia's Arms, whom I knew to be a handome Woman, and hop'd he might have a mind to her, or the Curioity at leat to ee her; but my Addres was lot upon a Man obtinately faithfull, and produc'd no other Eruit but naueous Aurances of his Truth and Tendernes for me. You did not much oblige me in that particular, Madam, (ays Meharen) and when you have occaion again to dream, to be rid of one troubleome to you, let me intreat you it may not be at your Friends cot. How, (replies Hattige) would you take it ill the King hould do as much for you, as you do for him? Yes without
doubt, (ays Meharen) for I do it not for that purpoe, that he hould do as much for me. Well, (anwers Hattige) if he do not, another will. I fear not that,(replies Meharen) I know my Wife very well, and am perwaded She is Fool enough to die, rather than do me uch an Jnjury, though the King hould tempt her. She quarrels with me every day, for but letting the Slaves come into her Chamber; and I dare engage once more, he would rather dye than appear to another Man, though the bet of my Friends.

This pleaant Dialogue had very different Effects on the two Auditors, who were ready ometimes to laugh, and ometimes to be angry: The King all the while had Roukia in his Arms, and queez'd her Hand when they poke of her. She did as
much to him upon the like Occaion. True it is, he had mall Kindnes for Hattige after he had found her fale, and les a great deal after he fell in love with Roukia. But it cannot but vex one to ee a Mitres (though foraken) in the Arms of another, epecially of one Inferiour to himelf: Setting aide the Crown, yet Meharen was not comparable to the King for Vigor or good Meen: He was not very old, yet not o young as the King, and a hundred times harder favour'd.

Pleaant as the King was, at dumb Raillery, with Roukia, and preing her hand, yet he was mad to hear what was poken; and any one, but Meharen (of whom he took very pleaant Revenge) hould have felt terrible Effects of his Anger. Roukia, but for Hattige, had born her part of
the Sorrow: but finding by her, her Buines with the King went on the better, and that he had paid her Husband in his own Coyn, he thought he had all the Reaon in the world to rejoyce.

But this new pair of Lovers had their Deign, and were not come into the Grotto only to talk: the Scene was going to alter. But the King was o little complaiant, that he had not the Patience to ee the bet Act of the Play; but riing up with a great noie; Meharen, (ays he, with a voice would have made the mot Confident quake) Is it thus you erve me? Is this your Execution of the Orders I gave you? 'Tis hard to repreent the atonihment, the fear and confuion of our Shepherd and Shepherdes, when they heard the King. Meharen fell at his Feet, with his Face to
the Ground, and not able for ome time to ay a word. And you Fale One, (ays the King to Hattige) you Baggage without Honour or Truth, is this your requitall of the Obligations I put upon you, in making you what you are?

There was harher Language in the cae, but I will not trouble you with it: I mut draw to an End. The Mater-Gardiner being a little recover'd of his Fright, though labouring till under the Apprehenions of Death, did all he could, (not to excue himelf, there being no colour for it, but) to take all the Fault on himelf, and make Hattige appear les faulty, whom he would needs endeavour to ave, by offering his Life as a Sacrifice for her. The King aid he would accept of it, provided a Peron he had with him would be content, and with
that he made Roukia draw near, who had not yet appear'd on the Stage.

Meharen was one of thoe Husbands, who though they love their Wives well, cannot forbear hunting other Mens Game. He had been in love with Hattige when he was at the Janizaries. And the choice the King had made of her for his Mitres, had but increas'd Meharen's Paion: So that he had everal times apply'd himelf to Zara, whom he knew to be a Mitres of that Trade, and found faithful on other Occaions: The Liberty he had to enter at pleaure the Garden of the Seraglio, contributed much to the good Fortunes Zara procur'd him. But as for Hattige, he thought her then o inacceible, he had almot diwaded him from any thoughts of
her, till the Digrace of his Nephew, which, intead of frighting Zara, encourag'd her to make a Trial of what he deir'd her; who no ooner had the Oppertunity of peaking to Hattige, but the Bargain was made. Little did Meharen think it mut have cot him his Wife, and his Conternation was yet greater, when he heard her Voice, than when he heard the Kings: He knew not what to do or ay, he aw himelf paid in his own Coin, and without caue of Complaint: He puffed out his Rage in great fighs. The King triumph'd, and to encreae Meharen's depair, and the pleaure he took to overwhelm him with Grief and Confuion, he commanded him to acquaint him with the Particulars of his Intrigue with Hattige, how he came acquainted with her,
and how he got her out of the Seraglio. Our unfortunate Adventurer was forc'd to obey him, and gave him an Account of the Paion he had had for her many years, and was renew'd after his Nephews Adventure, which let him ee Hattige was not inenible: That Zara had been his Confident, and that very day appointed for their Interview, like a Man that leaves all for Love, he had not Power to execute his Orders: As to her coming out of the Seraglio, it was through a Window of her Apartment towards the Garden, and that he was let down in a great Wicker-Basket: The King had the Curioity to go ee the Machine, and found it in a Poture to help up the fair Lady, who had deerted it. But it was his Pleaure Roukia hould go up in her Room, and
that her worthy Spoue hould weigh her up intead of Hattige, whom the King gave him in exchange, though not to his Satifaction. However it was the Kings Favour to him. It was his Majeties Goodnes to do it: And I know not how he could have us'd him better.

Thus got Roukia into Poeion, not only of the Kings Kindnes and Care, but of Hattige's Apartment, and all that belong'd to her, who had not remov'd or taken with her any of her mot Precious things: yet Hattige was o far from being troubled at it, that he lov'd her Pleaure and Liberty o well, he would have given more than ever he was Owner of, to be out of the Seraglio. But Meharen, grown wier by Roukia's example, kept Hattige as cloe, as if he had continued in
the Seraglio. This quickly produc'd Diputes and Quarrels betwixt them, till at lat they grew weary one of another. Hattige to be rid of him pretended a Revelation from Heaven, which the Turks are very ubject to, and told him he was requir'd to make a Voyage to Mecha, otherwie her Sins would never be pardon'd: The Caue was pecious enough to oblige Meharen to give her her Paport, though he had not (as he had) a mind to be rid of her. He gave his Conent to the Pilgrimage, and ent her to Tunis, recommending her to Mahomet Bacabey, his intimate Friend, and praying him to furnih the fair Pilgrim with a Veel to carry her to Alexandria.

This, Sir, ays Razie, is the Story of my Mitres. You ee I have not par'd her, that I might give
