you a true Account of all her Adventures, which none knew better than I, who have been with her ever ince he was taken into the Seraglio, but never approv'd her Conduct; therefore he endeavour'd till to hide it from me, yet I knew all he did. Certain it is, had her Soul been Beautiful as her Body, there had been nothing more perfect under Heaven. She would charm you, Sir, did you ee her, and 'tis pity a Man as the Captain of the other Veel hould have her in his hands. She would be far better in yours. The Knight anwer'd, he had a deire to erve her Mitres, but not to make an Advantage of her. That he had been in earch of her on no other Deign: And if it were poible, he would at the firt Oppertunity et her at Liberty, and all thoe
of her Veel. But it mut be kept ecret, let if his Friend any way upected it, he might put a top to their good Fortune. Razie amaz'd at o great Generoity in a Knight of Malta, who ordinarily ue not too well thoe of her Nation, knew not what to think of it, but took it for a Miracle. She thank'd the Knight for the Favour he gave her hopes of, and was carry'd back to her Veel, laden with Proviions; which the other Women were the more urpriz'd at, having been ill us'd by the other Captain, whom they thought no more inhumane than this.

That Night the Knight did but think of the Adventures of the Lady, and as bad as he had been repreented, yet being young, he could not chue but have a mind to ee her; but he was affraid, the
ight might cot him dear, ince he found by hearing the Story of her, he had more than an indifferent Inclination for her. Few Knights of Malta, of his Age, would have been o crupulous: Curioity, if not Love, would have prevail'd over all other Coniderations. But this (who was Honety and Generoity it elf) made it his Buines to erve the Lady, without the leat hope of Recompence. Yet he lov'd to do things civilly, and was willing before he went any further, to peak once more to Gourdan, and was preparing to go ee him, jut as Gourdan came to him, a little more gay than ordinary. Well Sir, (ays He) how like you your Company? I hope you will excue me the eaier for what Love made me do. I can eaily excue,(anwers the Knight) the Love one has for a fair
Lady; but cannot excue a Man who ues them ill, as You do. I am more troubled at it, (ays the Corair) than you think, who know not as I do, the Women of this Country: they are humourome, and will never love a Man, but when they are forc'd to it by ill age. That's a curvy piece of Policy, (replies the Knight) and becomes not a civil Peron. Believe it, (adds He) it would be more for your Honour, to end her back into her Veel, than do her the leat Violence. He pake thee words in uch a manner, as made Gourdan redden, without anwering a word. The Knight proceeded to ay, I know You will not take my Advice, but I would do my Duty to mind you of it, and if you have any Value or me, you will leave the poor Slave at Liberty, at leat, to love or not love
you: for whatever you have to ay of the Cutoms of the Women of this Country, you ee the ways you have us'd to win her, have not yet taken, but ended quite contrary to your wihes. She is not an ordinary Woman, to be threatned, and ill us'd into Compliance. And could you have your will of her, pray tell me what Pleaure could you have of her, but would reflect with Diadvantage on a Man of that Eteem You are of in our Order.

This open'd Gourdan's Eyes; he imagin'd the Knight had been told of the Ladies Beauty, and was fallen in Love with her, which might be the reaon he poke in that manner, and hoped perhaps he would be uch a Sot to quit her to him: Thee were Gourdan's thoughts, who turning to the Knight; All your Rhetorick, Sir,
ays he, miling) will not erve your turn, you are too young for me. And without makeing a fine Speech, as you have done, I will only tell you, I will keep my Turk; and let her love me, or not love me, he hall not tir from Aboard me. But, Captain Gourdan, (anwers the Knight, omewhat more coldly) is this Turk yours, that you can dipoe of her in this manner? and have you more Right to her than I? I do not intend to take her from you: I have already told you my mind as to that—I know not, (replies Gourdan,haughtily) what your Thoughts or Intentions are; but I will ooner part with my Life, than that Woman; and hall take him for my Enemy, who hall but think to make me quit her. The Knight, little valuing the words of a Man, whoe Jealouie diturb'd the little Sene he
had, would fain have perwaded him by fair means. What I demand, (ays he) is but reaonable and jut, and if you are my Friend, as you have often aur'd me, you will not deny my Requet, or at leat, you will not force me to ue the means to et this Woman at Liberty. You will find it a hard matter to do, (ays Gourdan furioufly) and with more Strength than you are Mater of: and o went his way. This was high Language enough, for a man as the Knight was, and aboard his own Veel; but being as moderate as the other was brutih, he choe rather to let him go, than offer him any Affront.

This was the lat Viit they made one another; Gourdan was mitrutful of the Knight, and watch'd narrowly over his
Prey: But his Lieutenant gave the Knight an account of all, and offered him his Service: The Knight was o jut, he deir'd no other Service of him, but to deliver a Billet he would caue to be written to the fair Slave. The Lieutenant promis'd it. Razie was ent for, becaue the Knight, though he undertood and pake well the Moors Language, would not write it: when Razie was come, he wrote thus to her Mitres.

q.p: MAdam, A Man Generous and Gallant, as he, whoe Captive you are, is ncivil and Brutih, is deirous to retore You and s our Liberty: Make ready for the firt Wind that erves, and hang a Cord at your Window, that when the time comes, you may have Notice.

div.p:
The Billet was eal'd, and carried privately to Gourdan's Lieutenant, who preently convey'd it to the fair Slave, by the Eunuch who was his Friend. The poor Lady was over-joy'd at the News; but had been o accutom'd to ill Fortune, he doubted very much to obtain a Happines he had o little reaon to expect: That Villain of a Pyrat, (for o he call'd Gourdan) had tormented her that day wore than ever; and he was reolv'd, if he came again, to throw her elf into the Sea. The Billet brought her in a manner to Life again, and he never pray'd to Mahomet o heartily, as he did then to the Wind, by which he expected her Liberty: What hands oever he hould fall into, he thought it would be a Happines, if he could but ecape the hands of that brutih
Captain. One Night, as he leat thought of it, he aw a Man come in at her Window, which at firt frighted her; but his countenance made her recover her elf. It was the Knight of Malta. 'Tis time, Madam (ays he) to free You from your Chains: 'Tis the bravet weather in the world to return to Tunis; make ue of it, and allow me the Pleaure of doing this mall Service to a Peron, who deerves better to be erved by all the world, than ill us'd as he has been. I cannot tell, whether Hattige was more taken with the Knights good News, or his good Qualities; but after ome Conideration, he was o affected with him, to thank him; he embrac'd him, and was not able to ay a word: She was a-Bed; and as there is nothing o handome as a beautiful Woman a-Bed, he was o charm'd at the
ight of her, he was as much diorder'd as he, and knew not what he did. Having by her Actions expret all the Acknowledgments poible. I believe, Sir, (ays She) Heaven hath ent me the Succour you bring; but ure I am, the World hath not a Man o Generous and o Handome as You. The Knight had the Gallantry- to return her Kindnes for Kindnes; and helping to dres her, being in hate, he intructed her what to ay, and what Coure to teer to avoid meeting with the Corair. To end my Story, the fair Turk was not long a dreing. 'Twas not a time to be curious in it: She put on no more than was abolutely neceary, and (had the Knight pleas'd) would have got out of the Veel jut as he got out of the Bed. The Seamen were tirring, and fitting
the Rcpes to make for Malta,-though the Wind was not altogether for them: The Knlght help'd the fair Turk to get down at the ame Window he got in at, into a Canoe, he had provided ready under the Poop, and preently with the Favour of the Night they gain'd one of the Prizes, wherein he deign'd to end her: He took out thence all the Chritians that guarded the Veel; and having taken leave of the Lady, who would have been longer glad of his Company, he parted with a great deal of Trouble to go to his own Ship; where he gave Order, as Gourdan did in his, the Anchor hould be weigh'd, that they might Sail for Malta.
